articles.headline: New Orleans Restaurant Scene Rises, Reflecting a Richer City
articles.snippet: Eight years after Hurricane Katrina, the restaurant industry has become the backbone of the city, and the boom is a barometer of a more affluent and more educated New Orleans.
articles.abstract: Eight years after Hurricane Katrina, the restaurant industry has become the backbone of the city, and the boom is a barometer of a more affluent and more educated New Orleans.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — By one count there were already 65 restaurants on the three miles of Magazine Street, a major artery through this city’s upscale districts. But on a recent Monday, diners were eager for No. 66. The minute the lights went on at Ivy, an autumnal little lounge with an as-seen-on-TV chef, the curious were at the door.

articles.headline: A Second Act for a Top Wall Street Strategist
articles.snippet: J. Tomilson Hill, the former co-chief executive of Lehman Brothers, reinvented himself by applying his deal-making skills at the Blackstone Group.
articles.abstract: J. Tomilson Hill, the former co-chief executive of Lehman Brothers, reinvented himself by applying his deal-making skills at the Blackstone Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: J. Tomilson Hill was a well-known Wall Street deal maker in the 1980s, a skilled merger tactician whose work on the bidding war for RJR Nabisco earned him a role in the book “Barbarians at the Gate,” which memorably said he came across to enemies as “an oiled-back Gordon Gekko haircut atop 5 feet, 10 inches of icy Protestant reserve.”

articles.headline: Cost of Health Care Law Is Seen as Decreasing
articles.snippet: Because of a slowing trend in health care spending, the government is expected to spend billions of dollars less than originally projected on the law, and future cost controls may save billions more.
articles.abstract: Because of a slowing trend in health care spending, the government is expected to spend billions of dollars less than originally projected on the law, and future cost controls may save billions more.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The rollout of President Obama’s health care law may have deeply disappointed its supporters, but on at least one front, the Affordable Care Act is beating expectations: its cost.

articles.headline: Factories Worldwide Are Showing Momentum
articles.snippet: Figures showed factories in the United States operating at the most robust pace since the spring of 2011, and well above the level economists had expected for November.
articles.abstract: Figures showed factories in the United States operating at the most robust pace since the spring of 2011, and well above the level economists had expected for November.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bucking fears of a sharp brake on growth after the government shutdown in the United States and earlier signs of distress in Europe and Asia, global manufacturing activity sped up in November, raising hopes for a broader global economic turnaround in the coming year.

articles.headline: Amazon Delivers Some Pie in the Sky
articles.snippet: The plan announced by the company’s chief to use drone aircraft to deliver packages is visionary, far-fetched and loopy, as well as a useful distraction.
articles.abstract: The plan announced by the company’s chief to use drone aircraft to deliver packages is visionary, far-fetched and loopy, as well as a useful distraction.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hard to believe, but there was once a time when the visionaries worked for the government. Rebuilding a ruined Europe, putting a man on the moon, ending poverty, connecting the American interior with highways — these were immense tasks undertaken, and often achieved, by bureaucrats.

articles.headline: Kurds’ Oil Deals With Turkey Raise Fears of Fissures in Iraq
articles.snippet: Iraqi Kurds are selling oil and natural gas directly to Turkey, upsetting Baghdad and Washington, which fear a broader independence for Kurds in Iraq’s north.
articles.abstract: Iraqi Kurds are selling oil and natural gas directly to Turkey, upsetting Baghdad and Washington, which fear a broader independence for Kurds in Iraq’s north.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The sharp, dry mountains that run between Turkey and Iraq have long marked a front line in the battle between the Turkish government and Kurdish separatists where cross-border attacks took many lives on both sides.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: A New Wave of Challenges to Health Law
articles.snippet: Conservative critics, joined by their Republican allies on Capitol Hill, are trying to make the case that President Obama has overstepped his authority.
articles.abstract: Conservative critics, joined by their Republican allies on Capitol Hill, are trying to make the case that President Obama has overstepped his authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than a year after the Supreme Court upheld the central provision of President Obama’s health care overhaul, a fresh wave of legal challenges to the law is playing out in courtrooms as conservative critics — joined by their Republican allies on Capitol Hill — make the case that Mr. Obama has overstepped his authority in applying it.

articles.headline: Fates of Brooks and Coulson in Tabloid Hacking Case Are Diverging
articles.snippet: Once friends, colleagues and lovers, Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson are on trial on charges of illegally intercepting voice messages at The News of the World, but she appears to be faring relatively better.
articles.abstract: Once friends, colleagues and lovers, Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson are on trial on charges of illegally intercepting voice messages at The News of the World, but she appears to be faring relatively better.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Once they were friends and colleagues who reveled in the heady world of British news, politics and intrigue. Together they rose from the scrappy newsrooms of London’s tabloids to the heights of establishment power, she as head of Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper empire, he as Prime Minister David Cameron’s chief spokesman. For six years they were lovers, carrying on their affair even as each married someone else.

articles.headline: Google Joins a Heavyweight Competition in Cloud Computing
articles.snippet: The search giant, which for years has been evasive about its plans for the cloud, is announcing rates and features for a wide-ranging computing service.
articles.abstract: The search giant, which for years has been evasive about its plans for the cloud, is announcing rates and features for a wide-ranging computing service.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Google already runs much of the digital lives of consumers through email, Internet searches and YouTube videos. Now it wants the corporations, too.

articles.headline: Detroit Ruling on Bankruptcy Lifts Pension Protections
articles.snippet: Detroit is eligible to enter bankruptcy and shed billions in debt, a federal judge ruled Tuesday, while also finding that public pensions could be reduced despite a provision in Michigan’s Constitution.
articles.abstract: Detroit is eligible to enter bankruptcy and shed billions in debt, a federal judge ruled Tuesday, while also finding that public pensions could be reduced despite a provision in Michigan’s Constitution.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In a ruling that could reverberate far beyond Detroit, a federal judge held on Tuesday that this battered city could formally enter bankruptcy and asserted that Detroit’s obligation to pay pensions in full was not untouchable.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey, Bill Vlasic and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Bolshoi Dancer Gets Six Years in Acid Attack on Director
articles.snippet: A Moscow court sentenced Pavel V. Dmitrichenko, a former Bolshoi Theater soloist, to six years in a penal colony after a trial that exposed toxic rivalries at the theater.
articles.abstract: A Moscow court sentenced Pavel V. Dmitrichenko, a former Bolshoi Theater soloist, to six years in a penal colony after a trial that exposed toxic rivalries at the theater.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Moscow court on Tuesday sentenced Pavel V. Dmitrichenko, the former Bolshoi Ballet Theater soloist, to six years in a penal colony for ordering an acid attack in January that nearly blinded the theater’s artistic director, Sergei Filin.

articles.headline: North Korea’s Leader Is Said to Oust Uncle in Power Play
articles.snippet: South Korea’s intelligence service reported that Jang Song-thaek, considered to be No. 2 in the government and a mentor to Kim Jong-un, has been stripped of his powers.
articles.abstract: South Korea’s intelligence service reported that Jang Song-thaek, considered to be No. 2 in the government and a mentor to Kim Jong-un, has been stripped of his powers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-un, the 30-year-old leader of North Korea, came to power two years ago so inexperienced and untested that the reclusive government named his uncle as the North Korean equivalent of a regent to watch over him.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and David E. Sanger
